column2: Cooked food may get wasted in case of the wrong estimation of hungry people in the area.
column3: We need a national policy to set up community kitchens throughout the country

column2: India ranked 101 out of 116 countries in the Global Hunger Index, 2021. Many people in India are undernourished and are sleeping on an empty stomach. As the supreme court mentioned, it is the duty of the welfare state to ensure that all the citizens have food to eat. By establishing community kitchens throughout the country, we can ensure that everyone has access to nutritious food.
column3: We need a national policy to set up community kitchens throughout the country

column2: Due to the pandemic, many people lost jobs, especially those who are working in the informal sector. So, now community kitchens are more needed than ever.
column3: We need a national policy to set up community kitchens throughout the country

column2: Tonnes of food grains rot every year at the Food Corporation of India (FCI). By supplying the food grains to the community kitchen, the waste of food grains can be prevented, and instead that can be used to feed hungry people.
column3: We need a national policy to set up community kitchens throughout the country

column2: Many people, especially youngsters are willing to volunteer. But not many have access to volunteer options nearby. Once community kitchens are set up, many people will happily volunteer and will donate supplies too.
column3: We need a national policy to set up community kitchens throughout the country

column2: Implementation of community kitchens requires continuous efforts from the government. Many such initiatives from the government are neglected after a few months.
column3: We need a national policy to set up community kitchens throughout the country

column2: Europe is slipping badly behind in many technological sectors. More investment by both the public and private sectors is needed to solve this problem.
column3: We should allocate 3% GDP for research and innovation by 2035

column2: Without decades of basic research to build on, the development of not one but several vaccines against Covid-19 to battle the current pandemic would have been impossible.
column3: We should allocate 3% GDP for research and innovation by 2035

column2: Massive cuts to the research budget are leading to a tremendous brain drain and are destroying Europe as the home of scientific excellence.
column3: We should allocate 3% GDP for research and innovation by 2035

column2: To face future crises – from climate change over cancer to multi-resistant bacteria - we need a strong fundament of open research that will provide the solutions when needed.
column3: We should allocate 3% GDP for research and innovation by 2035

column2: a Europe-wide uniform high-speed train network will lower plane traffic
column3: We should build a Europe-wide uniform high-speed train network

column2: a Europe-wide uniform high-speed train network will create an affordable European travel card to make traveling by train possible for the majority of European citizens.
column3: We should build a Europe-wide uniform high-speed train network

column2: Crony capitalists are able to get away with just about anything. They enjoy the full support of money and the government in all their endeavors. Their decisions may even cause the economy to suffer adversely.
column3: We should fight crony capitalism in India

column2: Crony capitalists get an advantage over their competitors due to support from the government. Simple examples of the undue advantage they get may be in the form of easier loan sanctions, loan approvals despite adverse credit ratings, easier land acquisition, out-of-turn property registration, tender approvals without any past record of performance, etc. This ruins the reward system of the markets. A monopoly gets established in the markets which prevents new players from entering the markets. This leads to lesser entrepreneurial activity in the country. Decreased entrepreneurial activity leads to lesser job opportunities and borrowing.
column3: We should fight crony capitalism in India

column2: Crony capitalism has led to India having the world’s worst non-performing loan ratio. Lenders gave away loans to unworthy entities over the years despite knowing their credit backgrounds. The current amount of bad debts is approximately equal to INR 9 lakh crore and is expected to increase by INR 2 Trillion next year. The banks are left with no other option but to take huge haircuts (sometimes even as high as 65%) on the loans recovered. Taxpayers' money is often used to bail out these banks in order to save the economy.
column3: We should fight crony capitalism in India

column2: An atmosphere of decreased lending is created and, in turn, the economy gets slowed down. As can be seen in India, entrepreneurial activity is extremely low. Job opportunities are extremely low today. India is experiencing the highest levels of unemployment in the last 4 decades. The Indian economy has been posting 7%+ GDP repeatedly but yet the common people are suffering while the rich are getting richer.
column3: We should fight crony capitalism in India

column2: Space mining may be neat science fiction, but I doubt it could ever become a commercially feasible activity. column3: We should develop European space mining to reduce pressure on Earth's ecosystems

column2: Pushbacks are not per se illegal. On the contrary, if someone tries to enter from a safe third country into the EU, there is no reason why the EU should grant an asylum procedure to that person, knowing well that someone who enter the EU once, will never leave, even if the asylum claim will be processed with a negative result.
column3: We should end illegal pushbacks.

column2: Pushbacks should be a core part of an effective border protection mechanism of the EU.
column3: We should end illegal pushbacks.

column2: The EU allegedly values human rights, and so should respect the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Pushbacks are clearly a violation of basic human rights.
column3: We should end illegal pushbacks.

column2: We have the possibility to choose between life and death. Life is for me 'Green up to cool down'. Death is for me allowing drought, extreme rain, and water scarcity to rule our lives and use big tech to somehow survive.
column3: We should embrace the future of GMO

column2: The main thing that needs to be done is educating people. Most people imagine dangerous poisonous chemicals when they hear the words GMO, which is far from the truth. The truth is, as you said, everything we eat (both plants and animals) was genetically modified, just with a slower, manual process. Being against GMOs is like being against a tractor. It's just a tool to speed up what manually takes hundreds of years.
column3: We should embrace the future of GMO

column2: We have the option to cure hunger in many places, increase the nutritional value of food, increase yields of manufacturing crops like cotton, and make plants resistant to emerging dangers of climatic change and globalization like predatory fungi or insects that harm crops or by making crops resistant to drought and heat waves. It’s sad to see that it has the rest of the world is moving forward, we in Europe have been misled behind in this respect.
column3: We should embrace the future of GMO

column2: Instead of GMOs, we could refocus on plant breeding - less risky than GMOs and less harmful to nature. Also, I consider the statement: 'Humanity has been consuming genetically modified food for thousands of years.' misleading on purpose. Genetically modified e.g. 500 years ago by whom? The soft way how to sell GMOs, which were created only in the few last decades (as far as it is known).
column3: We should embrace the future of GMO

column2: I am not completely against the use of GMOs in general, however, I am against the use of GMOs in the way they have been used until now. Proprietary patented seeds, leading to the increased power of the aggro lobby (and control of the whole food system); Seeds that cannot be reproduced by the farmer himself (posing health risks if done so); Seeds degrading soil and harming the environment due increased (intended) use of herbicides; Often oversold yield benefits, which might actually be lower compared to crops grown with agroecological principles. If we can make GMO seeds that will lead to decreased environmental impact (which is often the opposite of what is often happening now), seeds that will not put smaller farmers at disadvantage (e.g. forcing them to buy new seeds every year), then sure. But not right now.
column3: We should embrace the future of GMO

column2: As women face violence because of their gender, they need special laws to protect them. But, in general, men do not face physical harassment just because of their gender.
column3: There is a need for 'National Commission for Men' or 'Ministry of Men' in India

column2: In India, it is very difficult for women to go to police stations to report crimes against them. Men’s commission may further deter them from approaching courts.
column3: There is a need for 'National Commission for Men' or 'Ministry of Men' in India

column2: If a woman is a victim of any sort of harassment and is in a distress, society will more likely to help her. But the same is not true for men. If a man is a victim of domestic violence or sexual harassment, there is no single government entity he can approach to. Moreover, society may make fun of him for being weak. This is the reason married men are twice likely to commit suicide when compared to married women. To address these gender stereotypes and discrimination, there is a need for 'National commission for Men'.
column3: There is a need for 'National Commission for Men' or 'Ministry of Men' in India

column2: As per the 2011 census, India has a 51.47% male population. India has a 'Ministry for women & child development', but none of the government entities is working on men’s rights. As India is a democratic country, it is unfair to neglect people based on their gender.
column3: There is a need for 'National Commission for Men' or 'Ministry of Men' in India

column2: With better and more stringent mechanisms and laws in place to deal with sexual harassment, rape cases, and domestic violence cases, unfortunately, there have been instances of misuse of the laws to cause harm to innocent men. Setting up a Ministry of Men would at least give such men a chance to make their case. This, in no way, is meant to undermine the case for the protection of women.
column3: There is a need for 'National Commission for Men' or 'Ministry of Men' in India

column2: It has been observed that in countries where the sex ratio is skewed against women, crimes against women increase drastically. As can be easily seen in India, crimes against women have been on the rise. Most horrific of all, crimes against minor girls have increased drastically since 2012. This paints a very grim picture of our society as a whole. The highest GDP growth rate amounts to nothing if our society itself is corrupted to the extent that it is right now. India has been a patriarchal society for centuries. To make a shift to an egalitarian society for women in every aspect of life, Indian men need to be re-educated and rehabilitated with the new norms.
column3: There is a need for 'National Commission for Men' or 'Ministry of Men' in India

column2: Drug addiction is a menace that has plagued Indian youth in recent years. The majority of drug addicts are males. A ministry of men can help solve the problem of why capable male youth of the country are resorting to such self-destructive activities.
column3: There is a need for 'National Commission for Men' or 'Ministry of Men' in India

column2: As per Article 370, people of other regions cannot buy land or settle in Jammu & Kashmir. This is acting against the development of the region. column2: We were champions of hockey even when we were not independent. We have won Olympic 8 gold medals in Hockey, the highest in any sport. We had a glorious past, and we should work towards restoring it. Making cricket a national game may overshadow hockey.
column3: Cricket should be declared the national game of India

column2: Apart from the raw passion, the money and fame that follows are blinding. Unlike other players of other sports, the cricketers even at the junior levels earn handsomely, which is also a motivating factor that this game ensures financial security provided you play well.
column3: Cricket should be declared the national game of India

column2: India has been performing outstandingly well in cricket for the past 20 years or so. It is the most popular sport in India. Children are madly passionate about it, people are deeply involved in the game, and there is a cricket critic in every Indian house. The BCCI has been successful in brilliantly marketing and encouraging the game as well. BCCI is the richest cricket board in the world and the richest sports controlling authority in India. No sports authority has managed their game so well in India as compared to BCCI. We have won 3 World Cups, 2 Champion Trophies, and many more prestigious tournaments.
column3: Cricket should be declared the national game of India

column2: Cricket basically originated in England and gained popularity in colonial countries as the English masters used to play. The fine Englishmen used to bat all day and the tiring bowling work was done by the locals of the colonies. This game is a sign of the presence of colonialism.
column3: Cricket should be declared the national game of India

No, of course not! It is time to make Europe fairer in a very practical and direct way, by abolishing tax exemptions for European politicians and staff.

column2: It is absolutely ridiculous to be spending money on these climate disastrous practices. The EU is nowhere close to keeping with the Paris Climate Agreement and is still funding unsustainable practices left and right.
column3: We should eliminate the outdated agricultural subsidies

column2: The agricultural policy (CAP) accounts for about a third of the EU budget, €58 billion. This vast amount is flowing into completely outdated agricultural subsidies that promote and support an economic model dating back to the 1960s, which produces vast amounts of CO2. It is not only the steel, coal, car, cement, and other industries that contribute to global warming, it is also agriculture that is not reformed and continues to operate under regulations that protect vested interests rather than really support building a sustainable model.
column3: We should eliminate the outdated agricultural subsidies

column2: Absolutely all such attempts merely lead to new types of misinformation. People get excited and carried away. They might go into the project with a clear conscience hoping to 'defend the truth' but end up spreading fake news and defending the point of view they hold. As Churchill said, 'the truth is so important that it has to be protected by a bodyguard of lies.' The good news is that people are adjusting to the new reality of ever-growing, all-pervasive misinformation by evolving a bullshit detector.
column3: We should develop civic education and media literacy to empower citizens against disinformation

column2: The EU is not a country, but a free association of sovereign member states. Associations don't have constitutions. We have the perfectly fine EU Treaties as the foundational documents of the EU. They must be followed to the letter.
column3: We should create a common constitution

column2: Veto rights for individual member states run the risk of blocking social progress.
column3: We should abolish unanimity voting

column2: The veto is rarely used, but when it is, it is almost always thoroughly justified. No, we must preserve the member state veto.
column3: We should abolish unanimity voting

column2: Requiring unanimity to pass legislation over certain topics is a terrible idea because it gives the opportunity to a single country to block a reform because they think they could get a better deal, meaning it's impossible to find compromises, as a country could always veto the legislation if they don't get exactly what they want. This makes the EU slow and hard to reform.
column3: We should abolish unanimity voting

column2: Qualified voting is enough, if the need arises, to ‘protect’ the interests, preferences, and ideals of all Member-States. Unanimity leads to blackmail and/or deleterious impasses, and stalemates. We all have regrettable situations. Never again.
column3: We should abolish unanimity voting

column2: We can't allow our prisons to be filled with curious kids and desperate people. The use of drugs most often happens within safe quantities or as acts of despair caused by stress. column2: The residents get to have a community of their own. They can interact, make friends and enjoy themselves together.
column3: Retirement homes should become more common

column2: Retirement homes are usually built in such a manner that injuries due to domestic accidents are minimized. Skid-proof tiles, arthritis-friendly fittings, etc are some of the features that they exhibit.
column3: Retirement homes should become more common

column2: The elders get to live a life of dignity. They do not feel like a burden on any of their relatives. They are also treated respectfully in their own community as compared to being ill-treated by their relatives.
column3: Retirement homes should become more common

column2: Medical facilities are readily available at retirement homes making it easier for the elderly in case of severe emergency or even the slightest discomfort.
column3: Retirement homes should become more common

column2: At well-maintained retirement homes, they get individual care for their condition, be it any kind of sickness, disability, or medical condition. Nurses, caretakers, etc make sure that they are comfortable.

column2: Any retirement home worth spending the rest of your life in is quite costly for a middle-class family.
column3: Retirement homes should become more common

column2: Senior living homes or retirement homes may sometimes feel secluded from the outer world.
column3: Retirement homes should become more common

column2: The residents may feel a lack of connectivity with their family members. Being away from the family for too long can sometimes be depressing for some people.
column3: Retirement homes should become more common

column3: Retirement homes should become more common

column2: 'Fair' taxation is a vague concept. Taxes are complex and countries want to avoid double taxation. Countries should be able to set their own taxes in a way that matches their spending and the needs of their citizens. I am against global taxes and against double taxation.
column3: We should have equal and fair taxation across the EU member states

column2: Today we live in a system where our public healthcare system is organized on a for-profit healthcare system, where we develop knowledge through taxpayer institutions and then let companies patent this knowledge for profit this has to change, we shouldn't let the greed of capitalists extort us, the EU should work to DISMANTLE all patents and make healthcare issues for all. The big pharma companies just drive up the price and charge prices, the EU shouldn't be just that to protect the interest of these companies like they do now.
column3: We should deprivatize the healthcare industry

column2: I think we should decouple for-profit medicine from social issues. For-profit medicine is a good thing because it enables the most recent emergence of anti-aging/rejuvenation therapies (e.g. Science-intensive healthy longevity technologies: development and access), state governed health system currently is not pursuing such efforts, even more, currently there are no clinical tests allowed on therapies that target just aging, that is not associated with the specific aging-related disease. So, it should be laudable that businesses are doing this.
column3: We should deprivatize the healthcare industry

column2: Unfortunately, vaccination has shown that it is unable to curb the contagion and therefore the spread of COVID-19. As a result, the EU COVID digital certificate is not able to guarantee the safety for which it was designed, demonstrating that it is primarily a tool of discrimination without real usefulness in containing contagion
column3: We should abolish the EU COVID digital certificate

column2: The technology-enabled economy of abundance without human exploitation you can endorse it. We should not hamper automation, instead, we should rethink morals about work. Let the robots do all the bad jobs and let human beings be free to pursue a creative and meaningful life

column2: You should endorse the creation of the European Army to defend the interests of European countries, fight against trafficking (humans, drugs, etc.), and be used as the arm of genuine European diplomacy.

column2: The rule of law varies from country to country, due to the fact that the concept developed in each country under the influence of local traditions. It's impossible, and superfluous to develop a uniform, EU-standard conception of the rule of law.

column2: Having all workers working in private enterprise, irrespective of size, share equity in the company they work for by default would motivate higher worker dedication, overall operating and productive efficiencies, improved quality, profit sharing, reduced corrupt practices in management through stricter accountability, work satisfaction - a win-win situation for all.
column3: We should have all workers working in private enterprises share equity in the company they work for

column2: It would be a better idea to abolish the European Parliament. It has become an ideological Kabuki Theatre. The Commission should be entirely under the control of the sovereign member states, of course, who remain the masters of the treaties.
column3: We should abolish the European Council

column2: Nowadays the voice of the EU in foreign policy and security is weak because any EU-MS can veto any decision in the EU Council. We have seen this many times when the EU-MS have tried to find a common stance on foreign policy issues but one has been able to deter the will of all the other countries. This is not a democratic way. The EU Council should be only an advisory group to EU Parliament, and the decisions should be made in the EU Parliament with a majority vote principle because they are directly responsible to the citizens of the EU through a truly European election.
column3: We should abolish the European Council

column2: Let us make the EU a fully-fledged democracy. In the classic three powers of democracy (legislation, executive and judicial) there is no place for an institution like the European Council. All legislative power should go to parliament — the executive power should only go to the Commission. The European Council is still too much-misused by the larger member states of Germany and France to push through their agenda.
column3: We should abolish the European Council

column2: Yes, child abuse is a terrible crime, but there must be another way, which won't introduce surveillance of all. This surveillance would affect all people and violate their rights to privacy. It could (and probably would) end up abused by hackers, totalitarian regimes, etc. for censorship of free speech. There is no such thing as a backdoor only for the good guys.
column3: We should abolish Chatcontrol

column2: Chatcontrol is a harmful norm: it violates the secrecy of correspondence, increases the indiscriminate and unreasonable surveillance of citizens, allows governments and providers to experiment with tools that can be used for worrying purposes
column3: We should abolish Chatcontrol

column2: Chatcontrol harms minors as well — it shifts attention to risks online, but abuses occur mainly offline: in families living in poverty and degradation; in the structures that should help them; in EU-funded refugee camps, or in countries with which we have diplomatic relations.
column3: We should abolish Chatcontrol

column2: Though our constitution guarantees equal rights to women in all aspects, the mentality of people didn’t change. There have been several cases of rapes, domestic violence, dowry, acid attacks, etc. that led to the formation of several strict laws for women's safety. In 2011, India was ranked as the fourth most dangerous country for women in the world (in 2018 India was ranked the most dangerous country for women) and worst among the G20 nations when it comes to women's security.
column3: We should deal with gender inequality

column2: Women are lagging far behind men in education. Fewer girls attend school as compared to boys and also their dropout rate is high. According to the 2011 census, the data literacy rate of women is 65.46% as compared to 82.14% of men. This difference is alarming.
column3: We should deal with gender inequality

column2: Though the government and courts are trying to bring equality to society, it has to be the people’s mindset that needs a change. And in big and developed cities of India, this positive change is quite visible but in villages and small towns, there is a lot of gender inequality to be dealt with.
column3: We should deal with gender inequality

column2: Microplastics are everywhere nowadays: in the water we drink, the food we eat, and the air we breathe. It is said that we consume a credit card's worth of plastics every week. This must stop before we consume an apple's worth of plastics every week.
column3: We should have mandatory labels on products about microplastic

column2: Not many consumers are aware of how many of their products contain microplastics because producers deliberately hide this fact by only referring to the chemical names of microplastics on labels.
column3: We should have mandatory labels on products about microplastic

column2: In order to in parallel raise consumer awareness about which products contain microplastics, the EU should introduce a requirement for mandatory labels on packages of products containing microplastics warning consumers of the presence thereof.
column3: We should have mandatory labels on products about microplastic

column2: the solution must be a combination of EU regulation of microplastics, producers proactively replacing microplastics with natural elements with the same functions, and consumers making more informed choices to reduce demand from products with microplastics.
column3: We should have mandatory labels on products about microplastic

column2: Earlier, there was a threat of coercion and booth capturing. Some people used to threaten voters to vote for a particular candidate. Using CCTV cameras prevented this to a large extent. But now, e-voting has the same vulnerability. It is difficult to provide security to everyone in their homes.
column3: E-voting brings more harm than good

column2: It is prone to hacking. Even when we are using advanced technologies to make it more secure, hackers are also using new technologies and new methods to hack. It may also raise privacy issues. Even though blockchain guarantees anonymity, there is a possibility of a hack to know who voted for whom. Hackers may even hack smartphones to know the details.
column3: E-voting brings more harm than good

column2: Still, the digital divide exists in not just India but in the entire world. So, this may create new inequalities where some people can cast their vote from home and some others have to visit a polling station.
column3: E-voting brings more harm than good

column2: Initially, India faced issues such as vaccine shortage, lack of availability of vaccines in remote places, etc. But now after solving all these challenges, the main challenge now is to vaccinate those who do not want to be vaccinated. So, by enforcing legal measures such as compulsory vaccination, we can achieve 100% vaccination. The government can help them in dealing with their fears by keeping them for a longer time in vaccination centers while having a medical team by their side.
column3: COVID-19 vaccination should be made mandatory

column2: If the world did not achieve 100% vaccination, a lot of new variants will be created. So, it is important to vaccinate all to reduce the possibility of new strains.
column3: COVID-19 vaccination should be made mandatory

column2: Many people are not taking vaccination due to the rumors that are being spread by anti-vaxxers using social media. Taking action against these rumor creators is much better for improving the vaccination rate rather than enforcing compulsory vaccination.
column3: COVID-19 vaccination should be made mandatory

column2: Widespread awareness campaigns involving local people can help in overcoming vaccine hesitancy. Innovative and creative advertisements can encourage people to take the vaccination. These methods will be much more effective than legal measures.
column3: COVID-19 vaccination should be made mandatory

column2: This way all EU countries have access to a single database which will reduce paperwork and registration and provide immediate and informed service without the risk of complications, especially in regard to medical history.
column3: We should implement a chipped medical card as a medical ID shared across the EU

column2: The EU Database should be made accessible for health studies and prevention in order to establish a European Basic Health care industry to overcome future pandemics.
column3: We should implement a chipped medical card as a medical ID shared across the EU

column2: No, just no. You have no right to demand that people put their entire medical history on a card readable by all countries. I would not put mine willingly. Now a common health card for the EU, especially for insurance purposes and very important medical info (implants, transplants, severe allergies, blood type) yes. This makes sense, it does not infringe on privacy and everyone will agree to such a card. The moment you want a diagnosis and other stuff, that's where you are way off. You do know there are medical data centers and archives for this stuff? Hospitals can access this. But this is on a whole other level and should not be via card and not like this.
column3: We should implement a chipped medical card as a medical ID shared across the EU

column2: Print media is more trustworthy because once the news is published, it cannot be modified or deleted. Whereas in digital media, we can modify or delete the contents. So, those who run the newspapers and magazines will be extra careful while publishing the news or articles. Hence, print media is more trustworthy than digital media.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: It is not eco-friendly, since print media requires paper that is harvested from trees.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: Print media is just one-way communication. It gives information to the public, but consumers cannot share their opinions. Even though some newspapers publish readers’ mails, it is not user-friendly.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: Print media cannot target a specific audience, whereas digital media can show different ads to a different type of audience and thereby can generate more revenue.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: Several online news websites are bringing their print versions to reach more consumers and establish credibility.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: Print media is not helpful for some people with disabilities, whereas digital media has accessibility options in general. For example, digital media helps people with visual impairment by providing audio versions of the content.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: When we read newspapers, there will be no distractions and hence we can totally focus on it. This is an advantage of print media over digital media, which can distract us a lot with its various options and clickable advertisements.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: These days, studies and work involve screen time for many. So, print media is like a break and relief. Moreover, at present more and more people are opting for Digital Detox time. Print media is super useful for them.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: Following Print media can save a lot of time because all the content is compiled in a newspaper or magazine.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: Still, some remote areas in India have limited access to the internet. Print media is a blessing for them to know the latest happenings around the world.
column3: We should subsidize print media

column2: Nuclear waste can very certainly be buried in Europe. It might even be a pretty good place to do so! There is a lot of rock where you are completely safe from radiation on the outside and it is not geologically active at all! Rather than putting it on an island where the inevitable break will distribute into the ocean, rain water, and around the entire world. Radioactive rain - cool ;-)
column3: We should ban storing nuclear waste within Europe’s territory

column2: This is a ridiculous proposition. No one is forcing you to take an unpaid internship. If companies are forced to pay for interns many just won't take any, which is a missed opportunity for people to learn skills. This is also difficult to regulate - will you ban voluntary work too? If not, what's the legal difference? Why should we not have the freedom to work as free interns for a company if we want to? How is this a good idea? This is just a restriction of freedom of choice.
column3: We should ban unpaid internships in the EU

column2: Members should adopt measures to end unpaid Internships causes they are a form of exploitation of young people.
column3: We should ban unpaid internships in the EU

column2: Young people may choose not to be exploited. My main problem with unpaid internships is that young people choose them because there are not enough entry-level paid jobs out there. Banning the practice will not change the underlying problem one bit. Reforms in the economy and education are the answer to your grievance, but those may not be solved by brute government force.
column3: We should ban unpaid internships in the EU

column2: I am for the ban on internships that do not provide additional education and skills building, which are low-level jobs with no growth prospects. Such internships should be paid definitely. But I am against the ban on unpaid internships which provide other benefits - continuing education, mentoring, experience, skills building, upon which the highly paid job can be acquired in the future. High-quality unpaid internships have an impact on inequality - currently, they put poor people at disadvantage, and hence they are a factor in sustaining the poverty trap.
column3: We should ban unpaid internships in the EU

column2: Nuclear energy is not safe and it is not green because of radioactive waste. It is only transitional. We have good conditions for sustainable green energy (solar, wind, hydro, bio-methane and their combinations).
column3: We should abolish nuclear energy only after we abolished fossil energy

I'm just saying that we must have a shared policy, in order to move in the same direction on this important topic.

column2: Taking unilateral decisions is sometimes important because dialogue and all the other ways did not work till now.
column3: The bifurcation of Jammu and Kashmir brought more harm than good

column2: Bifurcation can result in better governance and more efficient administration. It can also help in tackling terrorism.
column3: The bifurcation of Jammu and Kashmir brought more harm than good

column2: This may set as a bad example for the succeeding governments. Downgrading the status of a state to union territory can be taken as a precedent. For example, If the state government is ruled by a different party from the center, and if the center wants to take control of the state, this incident can be shown as an example to do so.
column3: The bifurcation of Jammu and Kashmir brought more harm than good

column2: This step may be used by separatists to influence youngsters in acting against the Indian government.
column3: The bifurcation of Jammu and Kashmir brought more harm than good

column2: Moreover, tourism and film shootings faced obstacles due to the militancy in J&K. Now as Ladakh is a separate union territory, it can boost its economy.
column3: The bifurcation of Jammu and Kashmir brought more harm than good

column2: Bifurcation of Jammu & Kashmir was done without consulting the people and local leaders of the state. Moreover, there was a blackout of communication channels and media, so they had no possibility of expressing their views. This sends a wrong message to the people and is against the democratic principles of India. It is also against the federal principles, which guarantees rights to states. Moreover, on the same day, Article 370 was revoked, so this may make local people feel like they have no say in the decisions that impact them.
column3: The bifurcation of Jammu and Kashmir brought more harm than good

column2: Further division of Ladakh into 2 districts – Leh and Kargil on a religious basis is facing criticism from the local people. This move could have been avoided to preserve unity.
column3: The bifurcation of Jammu and Kashmir brought more harm than good

column2: When Jammu&Kashmir were one state, Ladakh felt alienated. Its ecological and cultural uniqueness was not given enough importance and was often neglected because the culture of Ladakh and J&K are very different. Thereby people of Ladakh are demanding bifurcation for a long time. Ladakh’s local leaders feel that their region was politically neglected by the administration at J&K. So, bifurcating is a good decision.
column3: The bifurcation of Jammu and Kashmir brought more harm than good

column2: Europe should choose a common language. This can be the most spoken language by mother tongue, the most spoken language in Europe, or an international auxiliary language. The language most spoken mother tongue in Europe is probably German. The most spoken language in Europe is probably English. An international auxiliary language can be Esperanto. This then is a language that most people in Europe have to learn. Does the question remain what language will be spoken we talk with people outside of Europe? Will this be Esperanto or English? Next to that, I have the impression that English is basically also an international auxiliary language.
column3: We should choose or create a new European (or global) auxiliary language

column2: In Germany, a lot of company cars are not for business use but are offered to employees as incentives in order to use tax benefits and avoid the cost of payments to the social security system (in particular in the financial sector). This creates an incentive to buy heavyweight cars (be it combustion or electric automobiles). Also, e-vehicles consume rare resources for batteries like lithium and water increasing their weight. Therefore tax / social security benefits should only refer to the strict use of business reasons and not for cost avoidance to the disadvantage of the social security or tax system. Finally, this money should be invested in public infrastructure and public transport.
column3: We should forbid authorities to give tax advantages, or any kind of incentives, to companies providing expensive and powerful company cars to their employees

column2: I would suggest a general sustainability tax for all products, services & actions where cars could be taxed according to their environmental impact both concerning GHG emissions and local air pollution. Additionally, companies could lose tax benefits, if they use cars with big combustion engines. They could have tax reductions on electric vehicles or public transport tickets.
column3: We should forbid authorities to give tax advantages, or any kind of incentives, to companies providing expensive and powerful company cars to their employees

column2: If an employee receives part of his salary in the form of car and petrol, he will naturally use it more than he would otherwise, be less inclined to explore alternative ways of transport and opt for a bigger more polluting vehicle than what he really needs.
column3: We should forbid authorities to give tax advantages, or any kind of incentives, to companies providing expensive and powerful company cars to their employees

column2: How would you know how many cases where companies and employees rely on their cars? How would you differentiate between needs and luxury?
column3: We should forbid authorities to give tax advantages, or any kind of incentives, to companies providing expensive and powerful company cars to their employees

column2: To begin with, stop using the labels “Europe” and “European” to name the EU institutions and initiatives. Do not forget that there are parts of the EU that are not part of Europe (the Spanish territories of the Canary Islands and the cities of Ceuta and Melilla, for example, belong to Africa from a geographical point of view); also, that there are parts of Europe that do not belong to Europe (the UK and Switzerland, to name only two); the EU and Europe are not synonyms: Cyprus is a member state of the EU, but 'if' geographically it is Europe, so must be Turkey.
column3: We should enforce the rule of law, promoting respect for human rights without linking them to any alleged “European” identity.
